isis.stitle: Electrical System Troubleshooting Guide - 3300 Model - ELECTRONIC GAUGE CLUSTER - TROUBLESHOOTING

item.para: Before beginning these test procedures, make sure the vehicle batteries are at 75% state of charge (SOC) or higher. This represents an open circuit voltage (OCV) of 12.4 volts. Batteries with an OCV of 12 volts or less are either completely discharged or have a dead cell.
Check any light or indicator lamp filaments that are suspected of being open (burned out). This is done to avoid unnecessary extensive circuit checks.
Inspect all connectors for loose or damaged pins, wires, etc. Refer to TEST EQUIPMENT AND CONNECTOR REPAIR section in GROUP 08 - ELECTRICAL in the Master Service Manual.

When the technician determines that a fuse is blown, while checking its condition, he is directed to locate the cause of the overload condition and to repair it. While no further instruction on this procedure is listed in the diagnostic tables, the common procedure is as follows: isolate sections of the circuit, by disconnecting connectors, and measure the resistance to ground to find the circuit that is shorted to ground. Then locate the damaged spot in the wire or connector and repair.

Diagnostics for circuits that are malfunctioning by sticking in the on position are generally not covered in detail. It is assumed that the technician knows to check for a malfunctioning switch, relay, or solenoid.

step1.para: Gather information by talking to the driver if possible. Try to determine the exact symptoms by gathering relevant information:

step2.para: What else occurred at that time?

step1.para: Verify the problem. Is the complaint due to misunderstood customer selected parameters? Use an EST to review customer selected parameters.
Check for and record any logged diagnostic trouble codes.

step2.para: Do the logged codes correlate to probable causes?

step1.para: Were the codes logged about the same time as the symptoms appeared? Were the codes logged repeatedly? (This can only be checked with the EZ-Tech®.)
Are the logged codes related to other symptoms? Do they have a common cause?
Avoid preconceived ideas! Eliminate any non-electrical causes for the problem first (contaminated fuel, clogged air filters, etc.).
